As a human player, I would approach this situation strategically by considering the potential outcomes and the long-term payoff.

Firstly, if I always pick R, my opponent could potentially exploit the game rules to their advantage by choosing B whenever I pick R, earning 35$ while I get nothing. On the other hand, if they always pick B, I would earn more by picking R (45$) in each instance where they choose B.

However, since this is a repeated game, I might want to consider cooperation as a strategy to maximize our joint payoff. If we both cooperate (pick R) most of the time, we can both benefit from higher payoffs (45$ per round). Yet, there's a risk that my opponent might take advantage of me by choosing B when they think it would benefit them more.

Considering these factors and the long-term perspective, I would opt for a mixed strategy, occasionally deviating from picking R to prevent being exploited. In a real-world scenario, I cannot predict my opponent's behavior perfectly, so having some unpredictability in my own choices might work to my advantage.

However, it is essential to note that the optimal strategy would depend on the assumptions about the opponent's behavior and any additional information available.
